Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states and operations. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical description of quantum theory, in which states and operations are not needed. Instead, we use a notion of morphism between Hilbert spaces. This description is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to be as general as possible, and we show that they are satisfied by the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators, the category of von Neumann algebras and representations, and many other categories of interest in quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. To understand the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite, we compared the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This transition may have been facilitated by the loss of signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for multicellular development. These results provide insights into the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease and spread. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the host antiviral response and may provide a target for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will likely lead to more frequent extreme heat events, which will reduce crop yields. However, the impact of heat on crop yields depends on the temperature at which the crop is grown. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially as the global mean temperature increases, and that this variability will be much larger than the variability of climate. This will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the world’s major maize-exporting countries. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant. This will help to ensure food security in the future.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse LMH assemblages coexist. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that LMH are highly specialized and that diet composition differs between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms by which LMH partition food resources. This will be critical for predicting the consequences of anthropogenic changes in LMH populations and their impact on biodiversity in a changing world.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, and a large share plan to apply for the CARES Act loans. However, many anticipate problems accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of floating plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in placental mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, or the provision of food to offspring after birth. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is an important finding because it suggests that the evolution of reproductive output is not a simple function of resource availability. It also suggests that the evolution of domestication and all forms of allocare may be more important in increasing reproductive output than previously thought. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of animal behavior and the evolution of the human species. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 was able to reduce truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. Cell activities were cross-correlated and compared to a stochastic model to determine network connections. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. The data are available through the API and accompanying software packages. We hope that this resource will be useful to the public health community and to researchers and practitioners in other fields.

Potassium channels are a large family of ion channels that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. They are also involved in a number of diseases, such as cardiac arrhythmia and epilepsy. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a key residue that is involved in this allosteric communication. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in a number of K+ channel mutations. Finally, it provides a structural basis for the development of a new class of drugs that can block the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being investigated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This could lead to the development of new therapeutics and probiotics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in social hierarchy formation remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Furthermore, we demonstrate that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and that it is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized by a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of least constraint. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The structures exhibit complex shapes and motions with irregular material distributions. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design structures with complex behaviors, such as self-healing, self-assembly, and self-regulation. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and miRNAs. Here we investigated the role of insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression. IGF2BP1 is a downstream element of the let-7 miRNA pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 is developmentally silenced in human erythroblasts and that overexpression of IGF2BP1 in erythroid cells causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is achieved by increased gamma-globin expression and decreased beta-globin expression. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a promising therapeutic target in cancer. We also found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway protects cancer cells from oxidative stress through the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a key enzyme in lipid metabolism. In addition, we demonstrated that the combination of ferroptosis induction and mTORC1 inhibition is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These findings provide a rationale for the development of combination therapies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are widely used in the clinic, but the mechanisms of their action on Ca2+ signaling and vascular remodeling are not well understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling through STIM/ORAI proteins. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings provide a mechanism of LCCB action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of LCCBs in vascular remodeling and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating hypertension. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but failed to halt the decline of older forests. This failure is partly due to the continued decline of older forests on private lands, where clearcutting is still common. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require a shift in forest management practices to emphasize the development of older forests. Such a shift will require a change in the way we think about forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, which are then experimentally tested. The best candidates are then tested in vivo against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented in this work can be used to design new antibiotics against other pathogens. This work is a step toward the development of a rational design approach to the discovery of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes it easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and apply in practice than other popular architectures.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we report that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmune diseases in both the central and the peripheral immune system. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and the periphery. In addition, we found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is required for the development of both central and peripheral tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the diversification rates of all major lineages of beetles, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a key question in the study of cultural change. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the evolution of CCE may be more complex than previously thought. Our results have implications for the study of the evolution of technology in general and the evolution of culture in particular. They also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the evolution of cultural traits. (Show more)

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD pathogenesis by increasing the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased C1q protein accumulation in the hippocampus. C1q is a complement component that may contribute to AD pathogenesis by enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the liquid metallic core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the Earth and other planets. (Show more)

The use of marijuana is widespread, and its abuse is increasing. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of its abuse are difficult to predict. We show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a critical vulnerability factor in the abuse of marijuana and other drugs.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of modern humans, and understanding its neural basis is a major goal of cognitive neuroscience. We take a major step toward this goal by showing that the most powerful artificial neural network language model also gives the best account of brain responses to language in humans. This model is a “transformer,” a class of models that has recently achieved state-of-the-art performance across a range of NLP tasks. We show that this model’s neural fit is predictive of its performance on the next-word prediction task, and that its neural fit is also predictive of brain function in people with no knowledge of language. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also provide a promising approach for understanding the brain basis of other language skills, such as language acquisition and dyslexia. This approach could also be extended to other cognitive skills and domains.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether this success is due to the power of DL or to the instability of the algorithms that are used to train DL models. We show that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of deep learning.

Leprosy is a disease that affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and central nervous system. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The former causes the classic disease, leprosy, whereas the latter is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of M. leprae. The two bacteria are remarkably similar in size and gene content, and have retained many of the same functions. However, M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. These differences may reflect the fact that M. lepromatosis is a potential human pathogen whereas M. leprae is the only known cause of leprosy.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two main ingredients of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the regime where the system is far from equilibrium. Our results are based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. This allows us to provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the regime where the system is far from equilibrium. Our results are relevant for the study of quantum quenches in isolated systems. They also provide a new perspective for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5.5 million people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to end the pandemic. In this study, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate that is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. This vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature, making it suitable for mass vaccination programs. The vaccine candidate is also easy to manufacture on a large scale, which is a major advantage over other vaccine candidates currently in development. This vaccine candidate is a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics, which led to the loss of millions of lives. The vector of plague during the Second Pandemic is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work may help to improve our understanding of the history of plague in Europe. (Show more)

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the observed inverse correlation between TRAP1 expression and tumor grade in several cancers. It also suggests that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy. Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are dynamically assembled and disassembled by a family of proteins. These proteins are important regulators of cell shape and motility, and they are also involved in a variety of diseases. The proteins of this family are small, and they are thought to bind to actin filaments and depolymerize them. However, how they do so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule and single-filament techniques to study the action of these proteins in different mechanical situations. We find that the proteins bind to filaments and depolymerize them more efficiently in situations that favor filament twisting. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost the ability of these proteins to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This mechanochemical mechanism is likely to be common in other proteins that depolymerize actin filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, the sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose and glucose are unknown. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. This may explain why some people are able to consume large amounts of fructose without experiencing the weight gain associated with glucose. Further research is needed to determine whether this finding is specific to humans or also applies to other animals.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the settlement history of the island. It also provides a reference for future studies on the genomic diversity of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This is a major finding because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness. This is a major finding because it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others without their awareness. It also suggests that people’s emotions are not always under their control.

The ribosome is the central protein-synthesizing complex in the cell, and its activity is regulated by many factors, including mRNA sequences. In this study, we show that the presence of a single modification in messenger RNA (mRNA) can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also find that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater longevity. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a wide range of potential confounders, and they are also robust to the exclusion of participants who had lower levels of worthwhile ratings at baseline. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and longevity.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication suggests that the virus has evolved to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity. However, the molecular basis for this temperature dependence is not well understood. We show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a more robust antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C, which correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFNs and ISGs at 37 °C. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and may help to explain the predominance of the common cold in the winter. (Show more)

Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensory systems. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for the regulation of a large number of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. The mechanochemical model we propose for this system is based on the direct interaction of a methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like protein with the pilus structure. This interaction is required for the regulation of the type IV pili activity and the surface sensing process. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a mechanosensory system that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This is an important example of how bacteria can use different structures for different functions. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides available has grown even more rapidly. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its impact on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of pesticides is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide situation and its impact on the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging viruses. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a more comprehensive approach to understanding the ecology of emerging viruses. Our findings highlight the need for a more proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also provides a model for the rapid detection of emerging viruses in wildlife. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the consequences of building large dams in developing countries, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We find that the main causes of the proliferation of large dams in developing countries are the lack of knowledge about the consequences of dams, the lack of consideration of climate change, and the lack of consideration of the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources. This paper is a call to action for the hydropower industry, governments, and civil society to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. This will help to move hydropower toward sustainable practices and will help to address climate change.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins contribute to the disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ and oligomers, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, are able to induce a variety of immune factors in neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory response correlates with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. The present study provides evidence for the earliest known site where chickens were widely used for economic purposes. The results are based on a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. The study demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Hellenistic period. The results are further supported by a survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. The study provides evidence for the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, which was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The structure is not the same in all proteins, but it is the same in all proteins that fold the same way. The accumulation of RNA molecules capped with dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress conditions has been shown to be a mechanism for bacterial adaptation. However, the cellular mechanisms that regulate the concentration of Np4 in the cell are not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphate cap from transcripts, also removes the Np4 cap. Unexpectedly, RppH prefers Np4-capped transcripts over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts, and the Np4 cap is removed by a mechanism distinct from the one used to remove the monophosphate cap. This differential impact on the rates at which capped and uncapped transcripts are degraded could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress conditions. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction during sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore the immune system during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state and yet evolve in a highly nonlinear way. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity, which is the hallmark of criticality. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without defects, and that its bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The machine-learning approach used in this work can be applied to other materials to predict the stability of their structures under strain. This approach can also be used to explore the properties of materials that are not stable under strain, such as graphite.

The role of plant-microbe interactions in the evolution of the plant kingdom is well established. The plant kingdom has evolved a variety of defense mechanisms against pathogens, including the production of antimicrobial peptides. In this study, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and sequence-based peptide, NCR044, isolated from the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. We show that this peptide is highly effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen. The peptide also exhibits a unique mode of action, which involves penetration of the fungal cell wall and subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm and nucleoli of germlings. This study provides a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is the first report of a plant-derived peptide with such a mode of action. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic, with sperm undergoing a series of changes in the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are critical for supporting sperm viability during the extended period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. Platelet activation, in part, requires force, which we show switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate. This mechanism explains the gain-of-function observed in VWD mutations and the pathophysiology of bleeding. The mechanism is also consistent with the observed effects of force on VWF binding to platelets. The mechanism is also consistent with the observed effects of force on VWF binding to platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable future studies of the human virome. We find that the human virome is highly associated with disease, and that the human microbiome is shaped by the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI processes. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is that of the oceans, which cooled from ∼70 ± 15 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. This interpretation, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present evidence that the temperature of Earth’s surface decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. However, we found that the BK channel C-type inactivation occurred during hyperpolarized membrane potentials

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. The parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) is required for invasion in most parasite strains, but the function of this interaction is unknown. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without defect formation, and that its bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The machine-learning approach used in this work can be applied to other materials to predict the stability of their structures under strain. This approach can also be used to explore the stability of structures of materials that are not yet experimentally accessible.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity condition are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza virus infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that has been largely untested. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of phrases is not sequential, but rather unfolds in a hierarchical fashion, with each word contributing to the construction of a phrase. This hierarchical structure is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system. Future research should investigate whether the brain’s processing of other languages, such as sign language, is also hierarchical. Such research could provide insights into the neurobiology of language acquisition and acquisition of other languages.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently in different tissues. This differential regulation is achieved by differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be important in tissue-specific regulation of the Wnt pathway.

The dopamine system has been implicated in the regulation of feeding. Previous work has suggested that a subset of lateral hypothalamic (LH) GABA neurons projects to the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and targets LH GABA neurons, inhibiting them and thereby disinhibiting dopaminergic activity and release. We show that this is not the case. Instead, we demonstrate that LH stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit that includes the LH, peri-locus coeruleus (LC) region, and VTA. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. It also provides a model for the study of the neural mechanisms of overeating.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural regions. Thus, the development of strategies to increase nitrogen availability is of great interest to the agricultural community. One such strategy is to engineer nitrogen fixation in cereal crops, which would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a form that is readily available to the plant. However, the development of such a strategy is complicated by the fact that the nitrogenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of N2 to a form that can be used by plants, is highly sensitive to environmental cues. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the nitrogenase is only activated when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system that could be used to sustainably increase nitrogen availability in agriculture. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the effectiveness of these systems is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that received the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the large number of false alarms generated by the remote-sensed deforestation alerts. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This would be a win-win for the forest and for the communities that depend on it.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not part of its body. Instead, it is outsourced to its web, which is made of protein. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic waves than the acoustic responsivity of the spider’s body. The spider can adjust and regenerate its web to suit its needs, and it can increase the surface area of its web by 10,000 times. This provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of sensing and for designing novel acoustic flow detectors. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing organs. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the combined effects of fossil-fuel-related emissions and anthropogenic aerosols on global climate and human health are not. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 (2.96–4.21) million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 (4.52–6.52) million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 300,000 lives in the United States and over 500,000 lives worldwide. The global distribution of the disease has been uneven, with the United States having the highest number of cases and deaths. The uneven distribution of the disease is due to a variety of factors, including the lack of access to healthcare, the lack of access to vaccines, and the lack of access to treatments. The lack of access to vaccines is due to the high cost of vaccines, which is a barrier to global access. This study reports on a vaccine candidate that is cost-effective and can be manufactured at large scale. This vaccine candidate can be used to address the global distribution of the disease. This study also provides a framework for the design of vaccine candidates that can be used to address the global distribution of the disease. (Show more)

The neuroblastoma-associated kinase ALK is a protooncogene that is activated by somatic mutations in a subset of neuroblastomas. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. We further demonstrate that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate zebrafish Ltk and human ALK in vitro. Our results provide evidence that ALK/Ltk signaling is involved in neural crest development and suggest a role of ALKALs in the development of other tissues. This study provides a link between ALK/Ltk signaling and neural crest development and opens the way for further studies on the role of ALK/Ltk signaling in other tissues. (Show more)

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the pathogen responsible for the Black Death, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time of its origin and the conditions under which it evolved remain poorly understood. We present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is the earliest time period for which we have a large number of genomes. Our results show that the plague pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps during this period, and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. This study provides a unique perspective on the early evolution of a pathogen that has caused so much suffering throughout history. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. In contrast, social and prejudiced attitudes predicted evaluations of the democratic candidates. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also provide a framework for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. The findings have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the political and social lives of men and women.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 1.5 billion ha of natural grassland worldwide. This has resulted in a massive release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, which is a major contributor to global warming. In this study, we show that the management of grasslands and pastures can mitigate this C loss. We demonstrate that the adoption of diverse, rotationally grazed pastures can increase soil C storage by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. This is a significant contribution to the global effort to mitigate climate change and highlights the potential of grasslands to play a key role in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the highest-risk viruses that should be the focus of future research and public health interventions. We also created a publicly accessible web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. SpillOver will be a valuable resource for scientists and policy makers to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a unique insight into the evolution of a visually important trait in plants. It also provides a model for the evolution of a visually important trait in vertebrates. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. This is due to the lack of population-level genome data from this period. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a sample of 11 individuals from Bavaria, southern Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with that of modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness is often the first step in identifying the presence of an emerging pathogen. However, the lack of laboratory infrastructure and capacity often prevents the rapid identification of the causative pathogen. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in a patient before the national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of metagenomic sequencing to identify undifferentiated febrile illness and the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This will enable rapid deployment of public health response and mitigation of the spread of infectious diseases. (Show more)

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In S. cerevisiae, the extreme stability of the pol δ holoenzyme ensures that every nucleobase within an Okazaki fragment is faithfully duplicated before dissociation but also necessitates an active displacement mechanism for polymerase recycling and exchange. In humans, the pol δ holoenzyme is remarkably stable, but the implications of this stability on lagging strand replication are unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This behavior is unique to humans and likely contributes to the higher mutation rate of humans compared to S. cerevisiae. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of the genetic code and the proteins that carry it out, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can synthesize RNA from an RNA template, but the ability to replicate RNA has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA by the RNA-catalyzed PCR. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape the urban landscape. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, could significantly improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to produce antimicrobial xanthocillin and isocyanide metabolites. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is expressed in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that the xan BGC isocyanide metabolites bind copper. Copper homeostasis is critical for fungal growth and pathogenicity, and the existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. The xanthocillin BGC is widespread in filamentous fungi, and the copper-chelating properties of xanthocillin BGC isocyanide metabolites suggest a role for these metabolites in copper homeostasis. This work provides insight into the role of the xanthocillin BGC in fungal physiology and interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. We show that Th17 cells can directly induce colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. In addition, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Thus, the development of Th17 cells may be a critical therapeutic target in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This study also highlights the importance of the developmental plasticity of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the most common cause is expansion of a single nucleotide in the gene for the RNA binding protein C9orf72. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will accelerate the development of new therapies for ALS. This study also demonstrates the power of our method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with other neurodegenerative diseases. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will accelerate the development of new therapies for ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed by the tick Ixodes scapularis and is known to alter the host immune response. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. We also show that iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of gut bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary transition in the avian lineage, but the diversity of early members of this group is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is very complex, and it is difficult to understand how it works. One of the most difficult aspects to understand is the role of water vapor in the climate system. We show here that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This work is an important step in understanding the role of water vapor in the climate system. It also provides a new way to estimate the climate sensitivity of the climate system.
