Vertebrates have evolved a variety of mechanisms to avoid predation. One of these is the presence of blue-green tissues, which are thought to be aposematic. However, the biochemical basis of this phenomenon is poorly understood. We show that the presence of blue-green tissues has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans, and that it is associated with the presence of a specific group of serpins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in red tissues. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study contributes to our understanding of the evolution of vertebrate coloration and the molecular basis of aposematism. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a key feature of solid tumors, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key regulators of the tumor microenvironment. Here we report that HIF-dependent expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5) increases the expression of pluripotency factor NANOG, which is a marker of breast cancer stem cells. ALKBH5 expression is increased in hypoxic tumors, and ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer stem cells in vitro and in vivo. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the tumor microenvironment may contribute to the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells. This may be a mechanism by which hypoxia promotes breast cancer progression. Our findings may also have implications for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was made from the skin of animals, and the source of this animal skin has been a long-standing controversy. We report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. This method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to extract protein from the parchment surface, followed by peptide mass fingerprinting. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did find evidence for the use of more than one species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used in other books and manuscripts. This would be of great interest to codicologists, who are interested in the source of parchment used in the production of early printed books. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. Understanding the extinction requires an accurate and precise age model. The age model for the extinction is currently based on a single U-Pb date for a volcanic ash bed. We present five U-Pb dates for volcanic ash beds from the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China. The new dates define an extinction age of 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The extinction is followed by a period of rapid carbon cycle reorganization, punctuated by short-lived negative spikes in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The new dates provide a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most common mutation in the virus currently circulating in the population. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure of the spike protein and may help in the development of future variants of the vaccine.

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir [A. Moulin and N. Zamir, “Repeated games with Borel-measurable strategies,” Econometrica 61, 1007–1043 (1993)]. Our result is also a step toward the study of repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, which is a natural generalization of the study of repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and are also key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. In this work, we propose a new way of quantifying the chemical properties of atoms, which is based on the chemical potential of the electron in the atom. We show that this new measure is a very good predictor of the chemical behavior of the atom under pressure. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon. We show that human demography, rather than climate change, is the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has offset some of the warming caused by human emissions. However, climate change is still expected to cause more warming than would otherwise occur, and the risk of more extreme fires is also increasing. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to manage fire in a more integrated way with climate change.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health and development, but the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions in which the bacteria live. This glycan-regulated symbiosis may be a general mechanism by which animals control the activities of their gut microbiota. (Show more)

The study of text data is a rapidly growing field. However, the analysis of text data is often limited to simple descriptive statistics. This is because the study of text data requires methods that can capture the latent structure of the data. We introduce a method that can identify the latent structure of text data. Our method is based on a combination of two recent advances in machine learning: topic modeling and word embedding. Our method can be applied to a wide range of text data, including the National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics and to compare the gender bias of topics to the gender bias of the data. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This will enable researchers to study the latent structure of text data in a more systematic way.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its spread, and it has implications for the study of the spread of other diseases in the past. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important in the recycling of nutrients. They are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has led to the mass mortality of millions of individuals. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the tissues. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. This is the first report of a densovirus causing disease in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia. The genetic diversity is influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. The settlement history of Madagascar remains controversial, and our results suggest that the settlement was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations.

While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We applied this algorithm to a human antibody that is effective against the Alpha, Beta, and Gamma variants but not the Delta variant. We demonstrated that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against the Delta variant by ∼10- to 600-fold. Our results highlight the potential of our algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially develop antibody-based treatments for the current and future variants. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as those used in vaccines and therapeutics. Our algorithm can be used to identify the most effective mutations for each variant and can be applied to the development of new antibody-based treatments.

Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in a timely and accurate manner is critical to ensure sustainable production. However, the current state of the art in crop monitoring relies on satellite imagery and crop growth models, which are limited in their ability to detect anomalies early in the growing season. We propose a new approach that uses the vast network of crop experts that are part of the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey to provide a continuous and probabilistic measure of crop status. This approach is based on the idea that the subjective crop status reported by individual experts is a more accurate representation of crop status than objective models or satellite imagery. We demonstrate that this approach can provide earlier and more accurate predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural products such as livestock, fisheries, and forestry.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in the excitability of neural populations. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to integrate information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to integrate information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not well understood. We present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. The evolutionary rates of plastid genes are modulated by the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome, which in turn are linked to the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process is likely to have played a key role in the evolution of life on Earth. (Show more)

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is evaluated through a high-resolution large ensemble. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of high-resolution climate modeling for the assessment of anthropogenic climate change impacts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which these remarkable materials are formed are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material, which is the oldest anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, demonstrates that quasicrystalline structures can be formed under conditions that are not associated with meteorite impacts. This discovery also provides a unique link between the history of the 20th century and the structure of matter. (Show more)

Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the presence of which is unique to (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. A diiron enzyme in Rubrivivax gelatinosus is required for growth, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein that we term BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is characterized by the activation of microglia/macrophages, which are the major immune cells in the central nervous system (CNS). Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes ameliorated disease severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a minor role in neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past century because of human activities. This finding is important because it suggests that anthropogenic climate change has increased the probability of a drought like the one that is currently unfolding in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, but that this negativity bias is not uniform across the world. Rather, it is highly variable, and it is also highly individualistic. This work thus helps account for the prevalence of negative news content, but it also highlights the potential for more positive news content to be more widely consumed.

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) channel ORAI1 and the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 are important regulators of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Mutations in these genes cause severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and muscle dysfunction. Our data suggest that the dysregulation of store-operated Ca2+ entry is a common pathophysiologic mechanism in these conditions. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated store-operated Ca2+ entry, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also advances our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that aggregates spread through the brain in a noncell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a model for studying the spread of other disease-causing proteins. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTB4 generation and the generation of LTB4-dependent host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for purine and thymidine synthesis. Mammalian serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT) converts serine to glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In this study, we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, which blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a glycine import defect in a subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including super-aggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are composed of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis, become prone to aggregation. This metastable state is a consequence of the presence of a variety of proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This plant has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but it is difficult to study because of the small number of viral genomes available. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the rate of substitution is an order of magnitude lower than previously estimated. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been infecting humans for a long time. This is important for understanding the history of human evolution and the origin of diseases. (Show more)

The rate at which global mean sea level is rising is one of the most important indicators of climate change. In this study, we provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the time period for which we have the most precise satellite altimeter data. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This finding is important because it provides a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise that can be used to assess the performance of climate models and to plan for the impacts of climate change.

Pain is a major public health problem, with the elderly reporting more pain than today’s midlife. However, the elderly report less pain than today’s midlife in other wealthy countries. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that the midlife Americans who are today’s elderly had more pain throughout adulthood than today’s elderly. Disaggregating the cross-section of ages by year of birth and completion of a bachelor’s degree, we find that each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, while benzimidazole does not. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, was shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease, reduced virus replication, and decreased the severity of lung lesions. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health and development, but the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions of their habitat. This glycan-regulated symbiosis may be a general mechanism by which animals control the activities of their gut microbiota. (Show more)

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on transcription. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. The results from the in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This study also provides a potential strategy for the development of DNA alkylation-based cancer therapy. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that has caused more than 700 cases and 280 deaths since its emergence in 2012. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavage events. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved MERS viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and diet-related disease. This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60%. This is a large effect and could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering operations could be a cost-effective way of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and obesity. This approach could be used to reduce the environmental and health impacts of the food system more generally.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is therefore a critical target for cancer therapy. However, the surfaceome, the set of surface proteins, is difficult to study because of the complexity of the cell surface. Here we apply a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a panel of breast cancer cells expressing oncogenes. We find that the surfaceome is highly variable among the cells, and that each oncogene has a distinct surfaceome. However, the surfaceome is harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the cell surface and its role in cancer. (Show more)

The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or the outcome of the election. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail is not likely to have a significant impact on the 2020 election.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been shown to evade the host immune system and to spread rapidly. The molecular basis for these properties is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8. We show that the structure of ORF8 is highly similar to that of SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may allow for unique immune evasion and spread properties. These results provide a molecular understanding of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal of this article is to provide a clear and accessible description of the problem and its solution.

The development of vascular networks is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly induce the formation of vascular endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts. This finding provides a promising strategy for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model in mice. These results indicate that ETV2-induced ECs can be used as a promising therapeutic tool for ischemic disorders. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. The discovery of ligand-activated RTKs has revolutionized our understanding of the mechanisms by which RTKs regulate development and disease. In this study, we use zebrafish as a model system to demonstrate that the ligand-activated RTKs augmentor-α and augmentor-β are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized epidermal cell type that is responsible for the coloration of the zebrafish. Our results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which ligand-activated RTKs regulate development and disease. They also provide a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs in a vertebrate model system. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is characterized by insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and insulin target tissues caused insulin resistance and impaired glucose tolerance. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, leading to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction did not affect the HA titer of the mutant viruses, suggesting that the same amount of viral particles was produced. However, it nonspecifically increased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. The lack of conservation might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may serve as a basis for the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire in the United States. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. Actions to reduce the role of humans in increasing wildfire activity should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape the urban landscape.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This may ultimately help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that plays a central role in host–microbe interactions. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients relapse despite treatment with multiple drugs. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). In addition, we found that ROR1 expression was associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either drug alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. Here we show that a series of volcanic eruptions, which are known to have caused stratospheric ozone depletion, occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation. The coincidence of these eruptions with the onset of deglaciation is highly unlikely by chance and is consistent with a role for stratospheric ozone depletion in the triggering of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are a high priority for conservation and management, and where alternative sources of protein are scarce. This highlights the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our map of global riverine fisheries can be used to facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Show more)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the developing nervous system, but this ability is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the primary pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for studying the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult nervous system has a greater regenerative capacity than previously appreciated.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genomic stability. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In yeast, these sequences are well characterized, and the binding sites of the positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9 (PRDZFP9) are particularly well studied. In humans and mice, PRDZFP9 binding sites are largely defined by the presence of a 12-amino acid sequence, but the detailed recombination pattern is not known. We describe the detailed recombination pattern in a flowering plant, using a population sequencing approach. The recombination pattern is strikingly similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may be more conserved than previously thought.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal reflecting the activity of a large number of neurons. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of functionally related neurons, which are topographically organized in a small number of reproducible patterns. The present study provides a method for the direct identification of resting state networks in healthy and disease populations, and demonstrates that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, the dominant resting state network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. This method can be used to identify the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. It can also be used to assess the functional consequences of structural brain abnormalities, such as those observed in Alzheimer’s disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is present on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. In bacteria, the 5′ NAD+ RNA is important for the function of the NAD+ dependent enzymes that it binds. Whether this modification is found in eukaryotes is unknown. We show that the yeast genome contains a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs that have a 5′ NAD+ cap. This is the first example of a 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes can prevent the development of complications. However, the long-term effects of intensive therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and may explain the metabolic memory of intensive therapy. This study supports an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This work may help to explain the mechanisms of action of intensive therapy and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the maintenance of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Among these volatiles are several aromatic and aliphatic nitrogen-containing compounds for which the biosynthetic pathways are not known. Using an introgression population derived from the nitrogen-deplete green-fruited species Solanum pennellii, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of the underlying gene in transgenic plants abolished production of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in ripe fruit, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit revealed the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. This pathway is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a fundamental insight into the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. It has implications for the design of conservation and management strategies. It also has implications for the design of experiments to investigate the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, but how its neurons represent space is not well understood. Here, we used a novel method to record from many neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These results suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network from other neurons in MEC, which could help explain the puzzling discrepancy between the importance of grid cells and the difficulty of studying their organization. This method could be used to study the organization of neurons in other areas of the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and with a failure of the nigrostriatal system, which normally carries dopamine from the nigra to the striatum. Here we describe a previously unrecognized system within the nigral system that is also affected in Parkinson’s disease. This system is located in the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra and is composed of striosomes, which are specialized dopamine-containing cell bodies, and striosome–dendron bouquets, which are specialized integrative units composed of tightly intertwined striosome–dendron formations. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people themselves to gauge connection, and by third-party listeners to predict how connected a conversation will be. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of social connection, and for the design of technologies that can help people feel more connected.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of heart failure. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. STIM1 is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by linking the SR Ca2+ store content with the plasma membrane. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, in wild-type rice plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA is likely mediated by priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We also show that ether lipid metabolism is important for the regulation of the macrophage phenotype. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of ether lipid metabolism has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. These results provide a basis for further studies on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and in the regulation of macrophage phenotype. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in the excitability of neural populations. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing and may help to explain the emergence of language as a uniquely human cognitive ability.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall and into the plant cell. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the plant biology community. (Show more)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective with respect to the chemical concentrations it can access. We find that the network’s dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This bias is a consequence of the network’s topology, which is characterized by a high degree of connectivity between its nodes. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of chemical networks that can operate in environments with strong thermodynamic selectivity. We also discuss the possibility of using such networks as a building block for more complex systems that can operate in environments with strong thermodynamic selectivity.

The mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies that block the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. This change in EEG dynamics can predispose the brain to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures. They also suggest that the EEG may be a useful biomarker for the presence of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This may help to guide the use of immunotherapy in this condition. This work also highlights the need for a better understanding of the mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures. This is an important step toward developing new treatments for this devastating condition.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid global warming, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. To understand the potential for future abrupt climate change, it is important to understand the processes that led to the past abrupt climate change. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change that occurred ∼304 Ma, which is also unprecedented in the last 2 million y. We show that the climate change was driven by a global warming event that was superimposed on a longer-term greenhouse climate state. The warming event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, which led to anoxia and a biodiversity nadir. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the processes that led to past abrupt climate change to better understand the potential for future abrupt climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of deforestation in Indonesia, a major source of greenhouse gas emissions. Certification is the primary tool used by major corporations and countries to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the need for certification to be tightly regulated and for certification to be combined with other conservation and climate mitigation policies. This is particularly important in Indonesia, where the government has recently relaxed regulations on palm oil production. Our results also highlight the need for certification to be combined with other policies to reduce deforestation. This is particularly important in Indonesia, where the government has recently relaxed regulations on palm oil production.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis. It is essential for the formation of the fusion pore and the release of the cargo from the trans-Golgi network. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved from bacteria to humans. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex. This study also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, and the number of sexes can vary. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that polygenic sex determination results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination is critical for understanding the diversity of sex in the animal kingdom. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE, respectively. The photoreceptor-generated ROS are quenched by the RPE, but the ROS generated by the RPE can damage photoreceptors. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end. We show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of predator morphology, which is fundamental to understanding how organisms interact with their environment.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and there is a gap in the fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This gap is well documented for the evolution of stone tool technology, but the reasons for the lack of change in the hand are not well understood. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from East Africa that shows a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, which is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. This finding suggests that the evolution of the human hand may have been more rapid than previously thought. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for purine and thymidine synthesis. Mammalian serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT) converts serine to glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. In this study, we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, which blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a glycine import defect in a subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a particularly aggressive form of cancer. These findings suggest that targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for treating cancer, and may also be useful in treating lymphoma. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT in cancer therapy. This approach may be useful in treating other cancers as well. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
